<p>My Pony<em>, by Liam Rector follows <a href="http://www.adjectivespecies.com/2016/03/31/finding-the-animals-in-cowboy-poetry/">Shining River's article about cowboy poetry yesterday</a>.<!--more--> It is from </em>Cowboy Poetry Matters, From Abilene to the Mainstream, Contemporary Cowboy Writing<em>, edited by Robert McDowell, Story Line Press, Ashland, Oregon, 2000.</em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>My Pony</p>
<p>Coming back to you, my pony, whom I had to leave<br />
To make money, I proffer up the dire smidgen,<br />
The torn thing I managed to lug back with me,</p>
<p>Along with the big bucks: World is made of bologna.<br />
Like the pressed woods of my ascetic bookcase,<br />
Like the traffic jam full of air conditioning</p>
<p>And grieving music, world is pressed together<br />
As if my impossibility, my pony, as by poetry...<br />
How long I have loved thee to see you now grown old</p>
<p>Though still able—under all this weight—<br />
To put your foot to the far off, to the going...<br />
Carry me now, my pony. Carry us to where we buried</p>
<p>Those Clydesdales who once in soggy spring,<br />
In early morning, plowed those furrows which fed us<br />
Before I could no longer afford the farm.</p>
<p>I think we laid them down, me scrounging money<br />
For the backhoe, over there in the west field.<br />
I think we should go over now to the west field...</p>
<p>And the cats who used to run with us back<br />
In the olde days: Sartre, Huck, and the others—<br />
None lived to see fourteen, though all stayed relatively</p>
<p>Long for cat lives—blessings to them now, my pony ;<br />
Blessings to them who used to run and sit with us!<br />
And will I ever get to hold my father as he dies</p>
<p>And will he release me then from the fear of dying?<br />
Not likely. Probably not, my pony.<br />
Probably much more mulling through this membrane</p>
<p>Which passes so quickly, which stuns me and makes me<br />
Wonder how much longer we've both got here to ride...<br />
Ride on while we're here, my pony, and next spring</p>
<p>I'l bring Virginia, whom I've left back in the city.<br />
I'll bring her to you for her safekeeping.<br />
She needs the hurl and arc these fields have put in us,</p>
<p>Out looking: she needs the kind of joking past grieving<br />
We've come to together, thrown through the pressed world<br />
Where I went off to earn being hers and yours, your Liam.</p>
